Jacqueline es una mujer emprendedora que cada día trabaja por buscar un mejor futuro para sus 2 hijos, a pesar de las arduas tareas que desempeña día a día en la atención de su casa no ha descuidado su trabajo en su pequeña bodega, siempre busca alcanzar mejoras para la atención de sus clientes que son sus propios vecinos. Recuerda los años anteriores en que se asoció a una vecina, amiga suya, para poder invertir el dinero que ambas consiguieron trabajando un buen tiempo para esta pequeña tienda; con el tiempo ambas han crecido y su vecina también abrió una tienda de manera independiente. Ahora observa su futuro con grandes expectativas de hacer crecer su centro de trabajo y a través de las ganancias que genere ésta construir su casa y mejorarla para darle una mayor comodidad a sus hijos que la motivan diariamente.Es por ello que Jacqueline solicita un préstamo de 1000 dólares para hacer realidad su anhelo e invertirá en esta ocasión en la compra de más mercadería para su bodega.Pongamos de nuestro apoyo para que Jacqueline siga adelante en el cumplimiento de sus nobles anhelos.

loans.use: Incremento de capital para adquirir mayor cantidad y variedad de productos.

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Mrs. Ma N., age 49, is a widow who works selling rice and various kinds of Khmer food, earning about $6 per day. She has six children, two who are employed at a garment factory, earning about $70-80 per month each, one who is a student, and three who are married and live separately. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase more inventory and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of rice and Khmer food.

loans.name: Huneng

texts.en: Huneng, 30, has a small booth at her house where she sells snacks, beverages, vegetables, etc., earning USD5 a day. Her husband, A., does not work anymore so she has to provide for her family's needs by herself. She is asking for a loan of USD125 to fill her booth with more goods. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To fill her booth with more goods

loans.name: Ashurgul

texts.ru:
Ashurgul O. lives in the city of Yavan. She is 58 years old, married and has 11 children. Mrs. O. has a high school degree. For the last twenty years she has been raising cattle. Mrs. O. is planning to use the loan money to purchase a milk cow. She is going to sell the milk to local residents. This will provide local residents with a new source of fresh milk and fermented milk products. Mrs. O. is hoping to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian, by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

Одилова ашургул одинаевна проживает в городе Яван.Возраст 58 лет. Замужем имеет11 детей.Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Опыт в бизнесе 20 лет. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы купить дойную корову, для того Чтобы получать молоко для продажи. Этот вид деятельности помогает обеспечить рынок молоком и кисломолочными продуктами.Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow

loans.name: Mariam's Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Mariam is a 49 year-old married woman with 5 children whose ages range from 12 to 30. She owns a small charcoal store which she started in 1999, and is an African articles arts dealer. Everyday, Mariam works from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan of $775 to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending and tailoring.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 22 years old and is a single  woman. She owns a small shop which holds different comodities like sugar, cooking oil, kerosine, flour, etc.  She started this business in 2005, and she works everyday from 7am to 6pm and earns a monthly profit of about $110. She now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more items for her shop.

loans.use: To buy  more items.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 30 year old entrepreneur. She lives in Kisumu in Kenya with her husband and three school-age children. She set up a fruit and vegetable stall near her home early last year. Her hard work and determination have led to her success within this one year period. She manages her stall during the day and also offers hair dressing services to her established clients in the evenings.

Her profits pay the household expenses as well as her children's school fees. Mary plans to use the funds from her next loan of $600.00 to increase her stock of vegetables, establish a new beauty salon kiosk, and save the remaining amount to use in case of of emergencies.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To increase her stock of vegetables and establish a new beauty salon kiosk.

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en: Kweku E. is a car tires repair man. He is married but his wife's income from being an apprentice is not sufficient for them and their three children. Demand for his goods is high and he is looking to expand his business. He is asking for additional capital to expand his business to increase his profits.

loans.use: To expand his business repairing car tires.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi B. sells clothing. She is married, but her husband's income from his job as a repairman is not sufficient for Esi and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: As additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Volodimir

texts.en:
Volodimir is married and has two lovely daughters who are 3 and 8 years old. His family lives in Drogobych, where he also operates his woodwork business manufacturing wooden products and offering woodwork services. He has been working at his workshop day and night for the last 10 years. Presently, he has about $4,000 in business. 

Volodimir is a Christian businessman. He manages his enterprise on the basis of Christian values and ethics. He is also a skilled professional and his expertise allows him to run his business successfully. Volodimir offers only high quality products and cheerful and customer-friendly service. He is requesting a loan of 4000 Grivnas to purchase raw materials and increase his income as a result.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Bikombo's Tujiimarishe Group

texts.en:
Bikombo is 27 years old. She is married with 5 children aged between 8 and 1 year old. She has been a food seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Bikombo now looking for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour and bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mtumwa , who has a business selling food, charcoal, and firewood.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Rasela

texts.en:
Rasela E., 54 and married with eight children, has many years of experience in the shop business. Operating the shop herself, but with the support of her children, she sells to the general public seven days per week; her weekly net cash flow is about $330.

Rasela is requesting a loan in order to buy more products for her shop. She has two previous loans from SPBD, her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chicken, sausages, cooking oil, sugar, salt, flour, rice, onions

loans.name: Afolabi

texts.en: T. is a nurse by training but she is has decided to go into business. T. sells medicine, provisions, drinks and bottled water. Where T. resides, in Lagos, is a developing community so, as a health worker, she organizes health seminars for the local women on how to live healthy lives. T. buys goods in small batches but the demand for her provisions and drinks are high and she wants to meet the demands of her customers. She needs a loan to buy more provisions and drinks in bulk. T. is 34 years old and is married with three children. Her children are all in a private school in Lagos state, Nigeria. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more medicine and provisions to sell

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia tiene 47 años, es casada, tiene 7 hijos, ahora viven con ella 3 de ellos. Desde muy niña se ha dedicado a la agricultura, actualmente es una madre de familia muy eficiente, pera ello se levanta 4.00 am. para dejar listo el menú de sus hijos, luego se va la chacra, después de cosechar encajona todas las frutas para enviarlas al mercado. A ella le agrada mucho la actividad que realiza, por ello no siente que trabaja, lo hace con mucho cariño y además le es muy rentable. La dificultad es en el momento de transportar la fruta a los mercados y no tiene como  llevarlas. Este es su 4to préstamo con MFP. El dinero será invertido en la compra de materiales para la fabricación de los cajones que le sirven para embalar sus frutas.
texts.en:
Julia is 47 years old and married with 7 children. 3 of the children still live at home. From the time she was very young Julia worked in agriculture. Today she is the mother of a very efficient family. She gets up at 4 in the morning to prepare the childrens meals for the day, after that she goes to the fields. After picking the fruit, she packs all the fruits in crates to bring them to the market. Julia likes her work and it is a good business. The difficulty is when it's time to transport the fruit to market and she doesn't have enough crates. This is her 4th loan with MFP. The money will be used to purchase the materials needed to make more crates for packing the fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase the materials needed to make crates for fruit

loans.name: Adams

texts.en:
Adams I. is twenty-six years old and married. Adams lives in Atebubu in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana with his wife. It a mountainous community with serene atmosphere. Atebubu is a farming community and almost every male farmer ride on bicycle to farm. This has created a job for Adams. Adams is a professional bicycle repairer, and not only that, but he also sells bicycle parts. Adams has been in this business for the past four years, and through it he obtains his daily income to support his family. 

He travels to Alabar, a suburb of Kumasi, where he purchases his bicycle parts. He wants the loan to buy more bicycle parts to restock his inventory to avoid frequent traveling and to have more parts to service his clients. With the loan he believes he can be more resourced to expand his business. He is a member of a community group, ‘Ima,’ which means 'Amen.' Members guarantee for one another to access the loan and as social collateral to repay the loan. Adams would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more  bicycle parts for servicing and retail.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is a 35-year-old entrepreneur. She is married with five children who are currently attending school through the help of government free compulsory education. It is her daily dream to continue to provide quality education for her children to give them better future life.

She lives at their family house in Apatrapa in Kumasi. Within the community there are diverse business activities and most of them are petty traders. Akua owns and operates a little grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc.

She wants to use the loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With increased stocks of different varieties, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She hopes to repay the loan in due time because she believes the loan would boost her business growth. Akua belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame naye’ which means "God did it". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to take care of the household.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Nelly es socia del Bancomunal Maria de la Paz
Nelly es casada, tiene tres hijos de 27, 21, el de 13 años  están estudiando en la escuela. Ella estudió secretariado pero no ejerció, por que salió embarazada y se dedico a cuidar sus hijos, su esposo es albañil. 
Nelly sentía la necesidad de trabajar para ayudar con los gastos en su casa, empezó ayudando a una persona, por bastante tiempo, con la venta de productos por catalogo, hasta que junto un capital y decidió  inscribirse en la empresa para ser vendedora directa de productos de belleza por catalogo. En su casa tiene una vitrina donde exhibe los productos de belleza. En la mañana se dedica a su casa y por las tardes sale a vender, desde hace once años. Ha ganado muchos premios, por las ventas.
Desde que esta en finca, ha crecido en su negocio, ha podido comprar una vitrina exhibidor y tiene un stock grande de productos.       
Nelly necesita un crédito de 1000 soles, para  el pagar los productos de belleza, y poder sacar más.  
El sueño que tiene es  terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Nelly is a member of Bancomunal Maria de la Paz. Nelly is married and has three children aged 27, 21, and a 13 year old who is in school. She attended business school but did not graduate because she became pregnant, then dedicated herself to the care of her children. Her husband is a bricklayer. Nelly felt the need to work to help with household expenses. She began by helping another person for quite a while with the sale of products by catalog. When she had saved enough capital she signed up with the business to become a direct saleswoman of beauty products by catalog. She has a showcase in her home where she displays beauty products. For the last eleven years, she has dedicated mornings to her home and in the afternoons she leaves to sell her products. She has earned many prizes for her sales. Since living on the finca, her business has advanced, allowing her to buy a showcase to display a large stock of products. Nelly needs a loan of 1000 soles to pay for beauty products and thus earn more through her sales. Her dream is to finish building their house.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for beauty products and buy more stock.

loans.name: Josefa Del Carmen

texts.es: Josefa del Carmen Hernández tiene 54 años, su estado civil es soltera, y tiene seis hijos. La actividad económica de Doña Josefa es la venta de mercadería en general como ropa, zapatos y perfumes. Hace más de 12 años que se dedica a este negocio. Los propósitos de Doña Josefa para su negocio son de salir adelante con su negocio para que este se desarrolle. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo destinado a la compra de productos. Sus deseos son de realizarles mejoras a su vivienda para que el día de mañana  obtenga un lugar cómodo y tranquilo donde vivir. La cantidad que necesita es de C$ 19.500 córdobas a un plazo de 13 meses.
texts.en:
Josefa del Carmen Hernández is 54 years old, single, and she has six children. Her economic activity is selling general merchandise like clothes, shoes, and perfumes. She has been dedicated to this business for 12 years. Doña Josefa's intentions for her business are to continue growing. The financing is for working capital to purchase products. Her desires are to make improvements to her house so that in future days she will have a comfortable and peaceful place to live. The quantity that she needs is for C$ 19.500 córdobas (currency of Nicaragua) for a period of 13 months.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase stock of jewelry

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: La Señora María tiene 62 años, tiene 2 hijos mayores ,ella empezó vendiendo los remedios medicinales en canastas por la calle y luego de mucho esfuerzo y con la ayuda de sus hijos logro montar un pequeña local en el mercado del barrio .Ella le provee de remedios a las despensas del lugar donde vive .Es un sacrificio para ella porque se tiene que levantar en la madrugada para realizar sus compras en el mercado de Abasto En el futuro espera tener un negocio mas amplio y comprar un vehiculo para poder realizar sus ventas en el interior del pais .
texts.en:
Maria is 62 years old, and she has two grown children. She started out selling medicinal remedies in baskets on the street. Then, with much effort and with the help of her children, she was able to set up a small place in her neighborhood market. She provides the remedies to the small stores in the area where she lives. It is a sacrifice for her because she has to get up at dawn in order to make her purchases at the Abasto market. In the future she hopes to expand her business and buy a vehicle so that she can make sales in the interior of the country.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy natural remedies like camomile tea, boldo fruit,anise,flax seed, barley etc.

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en:
Lucrecia S. has already been a widow for eight years. She served as the mother and father to her three children. Her oldest Marlon is a 24 year old a high school graduate, Francisco is a 22 year old college graduate who works in a food chain, and the youngest is Wilma. Wilma is 18 years old and was not able to pursue her studies due to life difficulties. At present, the family stands firm and helps one another to surpass the hardships of life.

Lucrecia is a vegetable vendor in their village. Most of the time, she earns a daily income of PHP 200 that they budget for the immediate needs of her family. She wants to improve her business and for this she is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000. She will use the additional capital to improve her small enterprise. She is hoping that with the financial assistance she is requesting, and through the help of God, she will be able to expand her business and earn a higher income to better provide for the needs of her family. She is thankful that her three children are very responsible and helpful in their poor level of living conditions.

loans.use: To invest in her business selling vegetables.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia R. is a seaweed grower. She is 28 years old and has three children. Seaweed is a common type of livelihood on her island. Because of seaweed, more families in Bien Unido Bohol are able to send all their children to school and become successful. She was a student but she married so early she was not able to finish her education. She wants to provide a good future for her children. Her children will be the ones to realize what she failed to achieve. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy seaweed seedlings. The loan will help increase the size of her seaweed farm. The loan will also help her increase her income.

CEVI aims to help small businesses grow. It provides not just credit assistance but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for her seaweed farm

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: Gloria tiene 38 años, es una madre muy cumplidora con sus responsabilidades, vive en su casa propia, con su pareja y padre de sus 3 hijos, motivo por el cual está dispuesta a trabajar duramente hasta verlos profesionales. La agricultura es parte de su vida, y la fuente primordial de su economía, pero lamentablemente su chacra de gladiolos, donde hizo una inversión por más de 4000 soles, se inundó debido a las constantes lluvias. Ella y su esposo sienten la impotencia de reparar los daños, pero aun así mantienen las esperanzas de volver a sembrar y recuperar sus inversiones. Gloria está esperando que el agua se evapore, para dejar madurar los bulbos (especie de cápsulas que contienen las semillas) y los cosechará para tratar de recuperar parte de su inversión con la venta de semillas, Lo bueno, es que al recuperar sus semillas podrá volver a sembrar nuevas chacras que le permitirán recuperar su dinero en aproximadamente ocho meses. Por el momento, con sus otros cultivos podrá sostener las necesidades básicas de su hogar y la educación de sus hijos. Este es su quinto préstamo con MFP, no ha tenido ningún problema con sus pagos anteriores, ya que los ha cumplido con regularidad, en su banco comunal es muy activa y se preocupa por el bienestar de sus demás compañeras. Con el dinero solicitado comprará fertilizantes químicos para la siembra de otras chacras de papas y gladiolos.
texts.en:
Gloria is 38 years old. She is a mother who always takes care of her responsibilities, and she lives in her own house with her partner with whom she has 3 children. Giving her children the opportunities that they need to get ahead in life is what motivates her to work long and hard. Farming is part of her life, and a basic source of income, but unfortunately, her patch of gladiola, in which she invested more than 4000 Sols, was flooded due to the constants rains. She and her spouse feel unable to repair the damages, but they still hold on to the hope that they will be able to plant again and recoup their investment. Gloria is waiting for the water to evaporate to allow the bulbs (which contain the seeds) to mature. She will then harvest the seeds in order to get back some of the initial investment. The good thing is that once she has the seeds, she will be able to plant new patches, which will get her money back in 8 months. For the moment, her other crops will be enough to provide for the basic needs of the home and the education of her children. This is the 5th loan she has sought from MFP, and she has not had a single problem with her payments in the past, since she has always paid on time. She is very active in her community bank, and always thinks about the well-being of her fellow members. With the money that she's asking for, she will buy chemical fertilizers for her other patches of potatoes and gladiola.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers

loans.name: Mukaram

texts.en:
T. Mukaram is a married mother of two children. She sells women’s clothing in the central market of Istaravshan, and has been in this business for ten years. She has a wide variety of merchandise, which she sells at reasonable prices. Mukaram is trying to do everything she can to provide for her family and give her children a decent education. That is why she wants to continue expanding her business by increasing the number of her vending locations. Mukaram is requesting a loan of 2500 TJS to sustain her business and ensure it continues to provide enough income on which to live. More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase goods in order to increase stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: A new software system

loans.name: Luz Naciente Group

texts.es:
En el Centro Focal “Los Andes”, se encuentra un grupo de 15 señoras dinámicas que  se hacen llamar “Luz naciente”, están juntas casi 3 años y su presidenta es Estefa G. que tiene el negocio de venta de comida y requiere el préstamo para comprar insumos como arroz, fideo, papa y verduras, al igual que Estefa las demás integrantes tienen diferentes negocios como la venta de fruta, carne, cosméticos, zapatos, fundas y ponchos y también necesitan comprar mercadería y tener productos variados que ofrecer a sus clientes.

Todas las integrantes de “Luz naciente” asisten responsablemente al consultorio para hacerse la toma del PAP (Examen del Papanicolau).
texts.en:
In the Los Andes Community Center, there is a dynamic group of 15 women who call themselves “Luz Naciente” (Light of Dawn). They have been together for almost 3 years, and their president is Estefa G.. Sra. Estefa sells food and needs a loan to buy rice, noodles, potatoes and vegetables. Other members have different businesses selling fruit, meat, cosmetics, shoes, pillowcases, and ponchos. They need to buy merchandise so that they can have a variety of products to offer to their customers.

All the members of “Luz Naciente” have responsibly kept their medical appointments to receive their pap tests.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise & supplies

loans.name: Mensiwah

texts.en:
Mensiwah A. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high school.

Mensiwah sells fish at Ayensudu near Elmina, which she has done since 2001. Her husband is a mechanic. Mensiwah uses her income to pay bills.

Mensiwah will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mensiwah plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Yemi

texts.en:
Yemi sells chickens and also supplies eggs to women who in turn retail them to the final consumers. She buys layers which when fed continue to lay eggs till they are sold off. Yemi has been in this business for the past five years, but before that, she was selling second-hand clothes. Business was not moving well hence she switched to poultry farming.

Yemi said she is requesting the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase layers in large quantity at a reduced price. This, she said, will enable her to meet the increasing demand of her customers.Yemi is based in Lagos State with her entire family. She is 46 years old and married with seven children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed and day-old chicks

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Born in 1942, Lucy is a widower with five children, and five grandchildren below the age of 15, under her care. She lives at Mile 90, Nsongwa Mezam Division, Bamenda, Cameroon. She is a very hardworking lady. She was unhappy with the death of her husband and three children due to hardship. Though she did not make it through school because of lack of home training, ignorance and especially poverty, she is still determined to succeed in life and provide for her children what her parents could not do for her. 

With this loan she plans to invest in farming and firewood sales. She is going to provide her community with wood for burning and food for her family and community. She will buy seeds like beans and corn. Experience has taught her how to manage a business like this one. Besides that, the firewood business site is located in a very good area. She will use the profits for educating her grandchildren and providing necessities and medication for them.
 
Lucy loves GHAPE because of the low interest rate and the social interaction among members. These interactions bolster her loan utilization and management.   

 The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and wood

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en: Rice farmer Nieves A. is 50 years old who lives in Agusan Del Sur. Pleased on her growing rice plants, she is encouraged to take extra care of her field. It is her first time to join a microfinance. She joined CEVI because like her fellow farmers in her town, she could use the financial assistance to fund her farm. She applied for Php6, 000. She will use the loan to purchase additional farm inputs. Nieves anticipates a plenteous harvest.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Khalim

texts.en: Khalim S. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of soda and beer to sell.  Khalim is 26 years old and is Married with a husband that is a police man. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school and provide them with scholarstic materials  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of soda and beer to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
S. Stephen is an established man with an up-and-coming business. His business is with a variety of clothes: ladies’ suits, bags, dresses, children’s wear, men’s wear - shirts, t-shirts, trousers, jeans, belts, and so forth. His business is located in Mpanga market and he has stayed in his business for five years.

Due to the high demand for clothes in this festive season, Stephen wishes to stock twice a week. He is requesting the loan to purchase more clothes. His dream is to develop his business and be able to supply to others at a wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association Benkadi sont  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 2 enfants et  vivant  dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur huitième  prêt de groupe.  Tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de fritures,du charbon de bois, du bois de chauffe , d’huiles alimentaires, de savons traditionnels, des condiments alimentaires, de la restauration etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  2sacs de 100kg de pommes de terre, 20 litres d’huile alimentaires,  2sacs de charbon de bois, 200kg de riz en plus de 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 7 bidons de 20 litres d’huile et 400 morceaux de savons traditionnels. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent dans les différents marchés de Sikasso ville et à domicile, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of group Danaya of Benkadi association are married women who average 35 years of age, 2 children and live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods of Sikasso town, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institutionn inorder to meet the needs of their customers and they are on their eighth group loan. All past loans have been repaid correctly. They trade in frying, charcoal, firewood, food oils, traditional soaps, food ingredients, catering etc. With their new loan, they intend to buy 2bags of 100 kg of potatoes, 20 litres of food oils, 2 bags of charcoal, 200 kg of rice in addition to 5 packages of food ingredients, 7 gallons of 20 litres of cooking oil and 400 pieces of traditional soaps. They get their supplies in the big markets of Sikasso city and in the neighboring villages. They sell on the different market days of Sikasso town and from home for cash and sometimes on credit to a clientele made up of men and women. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 35 000FCFA each, of which a part will be used for saving and the needs of the family and the other part will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Judith Akinyi

texts.en: Judith A sells dresses, tops, inner-wear, t-shirts and trousers to an established clientele. She also caters for walk-in clients at the busy Manyatta-Koyango market (local market). Her business challenges are fluctuating preferences, customer tastes and needs (eg. customers preferring second-hand clothes) and strong competition. She is using the proceeds of KES20,000 to purchase one bale of dresses and dress tops. In the future, she wants to own a boutique, build a decent house for her family and take her children to a better school. Judith is twenty-three years old, married and has three children. She describes herself as determined and hard-working.

loans.use: To buy one bale of dresses and ladies tops.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna D. is from the village of Villanueva. She is 32 years old. Myrna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in this business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from this activity.

In 2008, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Myrna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros C., 51, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling watermelons, earning an income of US $10 per day. She is also a fortune teller at her home in the village. In the picture, she is preparing religious tools for sale. C.'s income helps to cover the family expenses.

C. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to buy more watermelons from local farmers in her province for sale and to expand her current business. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT MFI, Kiva’s partner. In the future, she hopes she will be able to have a bigger stand at the market to sell the watermelons wholesale because her family members are depending on this source of income. She also wants her children to finish high school and continue to a good university.

loans.use: To purchase watermelons for sale and to expand the current business.

loans.name: Eden

texts.en: Eden E. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Eden owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Eden joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita C. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old. Teresita is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Teresita makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Diana Luz

texts.es: Diana, es una mujer muy emprendedora, vive en el distrito de Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 29 años, es madre de dos hijos, ambos menores de edad, ella se dedica a la administración de su bodega, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo, quien es taxista. Diana forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Triunfadoras”, desde hace dos años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra de productos para su bodega, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1000 soles, que será invertido en la compra de gaseosas y productos de primera necesidad. La meta de Diana es ampliar su negocio y vender otros productos.
texts.en:
Diana is a very entrepreneurial woman. She lives in the Calleria District of the Ucayali region. She is 29 years old, and is the mother of two children, both minors. She runs a grocery store out of her home with the help of her husband who is a taxi driver. Diana has been a member of the “Las Triunfadoras” Community Bank for two years. The first loan that she received was for 300 soles, which was used to buy products for her store. Now she needs a loan of 1000 soles which will be invested in soft drinks and other necessary products. Diana's goal is to expand her business and to sell other products.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Scinta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks and other necessary products for her store.

loans.name: Ronito

texts.en:
Ronito B. is from the village of  Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 46 years old. Ronito is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Ronito owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling baskets the local community. Ronito has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ronito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronito is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ronito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sebastian

texts.es:
Sebastian es un padre de familia de 60 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa en el sector Laguna Chica una zona rural del distrito de Santa Rosa, ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde muy joven a la agricultura y a la crianza y venta de ganado ovino para sobrevivir, empezó trabajando como obrero agrícola y poco a poco pudo adquirir una pequeña parcela en donde usualmente siembra forraje (alfalfa)y tubérculos. El nos comenta que no puede sembrar toda la extensión de terreno que posee ya que, por la cercanía al mar, sus terrenos son salinos y los cultivos no sobreviven en ese tipo de suelos.

Por ello es de mucha importancia su negocio de crianza y venta de ganado ovino, ya que este le brinda los ingresos que necesita para mantener a su familia. El cría las ovejas en un corral instalado en la parte posterior de su domicilio y las vende a los negociantes que usualmente visitan la zona en donde vive. El forraje que siembra lo utiliza en la crianza de sus ovejas.

Sebatian desea brindarle mantenimiento a su cultivo de alfalfa para asegurarle a sus ovejas una buena alimentación, por ello se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de foliares para abonar el cultivo que tiene instalado.

El es una hombre bastante honrado y trabajador, su mayor anhelo es poder tener más exito como agricultor y seguir adelante con su cria de ovejas.
texts.en:
Sebastian is a 60 year old husband and father. He lives with his wife in the Laguna Chica secotor, a rural area of the Santa Rosa district, 30 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Since he was very young, he has worked in agriculture and the raising and selling sheep to survive. He started working as an farm worker and little by little was able to acquire a small land parcel where he usually plants forage (alfalfa) and tubers. He tells us that he can't plant the whole lot because of its closeness to the sea. Its land is salinated and the crops don't survive in that type of soil. That is why his business of raising and selling sheep is so important. It supplies the income he needs to support his family. He raises the sheep in a corral installed in the back of his house and sells them to dealers who usually visit the area where he lives. The forage he plants is used to raise the sheep. Sebastian wants to maintain his alfalfa crop to assure good feed for his sheep. This is why he is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles. He plans on using it to buy foliar fertilizer to fertilize he crop he has planted. He is a very honest and hardworking man. His greatest wish is to be able to be more successful as a farmer and to get ahead with raising his sheep.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase foliar fertilizer to maintain his alfalfa crop.

loans.name: Cruz Antonio

texts.es:
El Señor Cruz Antonio T. G., es trabajador de la Empresa Lotería Nacional de Chinandega de la cual tenemos un convenio con dicha empresa tiene de laborar para esa institución 10 años como vigilante.
Es casado son cuatro en su familia el, su esposa y dos hijos de los cuales los tres dependen de él es un hombre trabajador y luchador trabaja de 24 horas descansando las 24 horas seguidas pero él en tiempos libre vende raspaditas.
El financiamiento lo solicita para realizarle alguna mejora a su hogar o para cubrir gastos personales se siente muy agradecido con estos financiamientos que le han brindado gracias al convenio que adquirió su empresa donde trabaja con ceprodel
texts.en:
Sr. Cruz Antonio T. G. is an employee of the National Lottery Enterprise in Chinandega, with which CEPRODEL has a business contract. He has been working for this institution as a security guard for ten years.

He is married and lives with his wife and two children who are dependent on him. Cruz struggles and works for 24 hours straight and then rests for 24 hours. In his free time, he sells lottery scratch-off tickets.

The loan he is requesting will be used to make some improvements to his home and also cover personal expenses. He is very grateful for these loans which have been provided as a result of an agreement between CEPRODEL and his employer.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Make a few improvements to his home & pay some personal expenses
